PART 3: Short texts (Questions 16-30)
Level: B1

Text 1: Global Polio Eradication Progress

Polio, once a devastating disease that paralyzed thousands of children every year, is now on the verge of being completely eradicated. In 1988, when the Global Polio Eradication Initiative (GPEI) was launched, polio was endemic in 125 countries and paralyzed more than 350,000 children annually. By 2024, that number had dropped by over 99%, with only a handful of cases reported worldwide.

The success has been driven largely by massive vaccination campaigns, particularly in developing countries. Health workers travel to remote villages and conflict zones to administer the oral polio vaccine, often going door to door. However, the final stages of eradication have proven the most difficult. The remaining cases are concentrated in Afghanistan and Pakistan, where ongoing conflict, population displacement, and vaccine misinformation continue to pose challenges.

Public health officials remain optimistic but caution that surveillance and vaccination efforts must continue until the disease is fully eliminated. History has shown that even a single unvaccinated community can lead to a resurgence of the virus.

(Original content — Study2One, based on WHO reports)

Text 2: Hospital Fire Safety Protocol

All hospital staff must be familiar with the RACE protocol in the event of a fire. RACE stands for: Rescue anyone in immediate danger, Activate the fire alarm and call the emergency number, Contain the fire by closing doors and windows, and Evacuate patients and staff through the nearest safe exit.

Staff should never use elevators during a fire. Patients who cannot walk must be moved using evacuation chairs or blanket drags. Each department must conduct fire drills at least twice a year, and all employees must know the location of fire extinguishers, emergency exits, and assembly points on their floor.

Smoking is strictly prohibited inside all hospital buildings. Flammable materials must be stored in designated areas only. Any fire safety concerns should be reported to the Safety Office immediately.

(Original content — Study2One)
questionText: What does the letter 'C' in the RACE protocol stand for?

options.text: Close doors to contain the fire.

Text 3: Blood Donation Awareness Campaign

Every two seconds, someone in the world needs blood. Blood cannot be manufactured — it can only come from generous volunteer donors. A single donation can save up to three lives because blood is separated into its components: red blood cells, platelets, and plasma.

To be eligible to donate, you must be at least 18 years old, weigh at least 50 kilograms, and be in good general health. The donation process takes about 10 minutes, though the entire visit — including registration, a brief health screening, and a rest period with refreshments — lasts approximately one hour. You can donate whole blood every 56 days, or about six times a year.

Common myths about blood donation include the belief that it weakens your body or that you can catch diseases from donating. Neither is true. Your body replaces the donated blood within a few weeks, and all equipment used is sterile and single-use.

(Original content — Study2One)

Text 4: New Surgical Robot System

St. Anne's Medical Center has announced the installation of a new robotic surgical system, making it one of the first hospitals in the region to offer robot-assisted surgery. The system allows surgeons to perform minimally invasive procedures through tiny incisions using robotic arms controlled from a console.

Dr. Patricia Mendoza, chief of surgery, explained that the robot provides a magnified, high-definition 3D view of the surgical area and allows for greater precision than traditional open surgery. «The surgeon's hand movements are translated into smaller, more precise movements of the instruments inside the patient's body,» she said.

Benefits for patients include smaller scars, less blood loss, reduced pain after surgery, and shorter hospital stays. Most patients who undergo robot-assisted procedures can return to normal activities within two to three weeks, compared to six to eight weeks for traditional open surgery.

(Original content — Study2One)

Text 5: Mental Health First Aid Training

Riverside Community Hospital is offering free Mental Health First Aid (MHFA) training to all hospital employees and members of the public. The eight-hour course teaches participants how to recognize the signs of mental health problems and substance use disorders, how to offer initial support, and how to guide a person toward appropriate professional help.

The training covers five common mental health challenges: depression, anxiety disorders, psychosis, substance use disorders, and eating disorders. Participants learn the ALGEE action plan: Assess the risk of suicide or harm, Listen non-judgmentally, Give reassurance and information, Encourage appropriate professional help, and Encourage self-help and other support strategies.

Course instructor Dr. Camilo Vargas emphasized that mental health first aid is not therapy. «Just as traditional first aid is given before professional medical help arrives, mental health first aid is offered until a person receives professional treatment or the crisis passes,» he explained.

(Original content — Study2One)

PART 4: Academic texts (Questions 31-55)
Level: B1-B2

Read the following text and answer the questions.

Text 1: Vaccine Hesitancy Among Healthcare Workers

Vaccine hesitancy — the reluctance or refusal to be vaccinated despite the availability of vaccines — is not limited to the general public. A growing body of research has revealed that a significant proportion of healthcare workers (HCWs) themselves express doubts about certain vaccines, most notably seasonal influenza and, more recently, COVID-19 vaccines.

A 2023 meta-analysis of 85 studies from 35 countries found that approximately 23% of healthcare workers reported hesitancy toward COVID-19 vaccination. The rates varied considerably by profession: nurses tended to show higher hesitancy rates (28%) compared to physicians (12%). Factors associated with vaccine hesitancy among HCWs included concerns about side effects, distrust of the rapid development process, religious or philosophical beliefs, and exposure to misinformation on social media.

The implications are profound. Healthcare workers are not only at higher risk of contracting and spreading infectious diseases but also serve as trusted sources of health information for their patients. When a nurse or doctor expresses doubt about a vaccine, it can significantly influence patients' decisions. Studies have consistently shown that a healthcare provider's personal vaccination status is one of the strongest predictors of whether they will recommend vaccination to their patients.

Interventions that have shown promise include providing transparent, evidence-based information about vaccine development and safety, offering vaccines conveniently at the workplace, engaging trusted peer leaders as vaccine champions, and addressing specific concerns through open dialogue rather than mandates. Experts emphasize that coercive approaches tend to increase resistance, whereas respectful, informational strategies build lasting confidence.

(Original content — Study2One)

Text 2: Impact of Air Pollution on Cardiovascular Health

For decades, the health effects of air pollution were primarily associated with respiratory conditions such as asthma and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease. However, a substantial and growing body of evidence now demonstrates that air pollution is a major risk factor for cardiovascular disease (CVD), including heart attacks, strokes, heart failure, and atrial fibrillation.

Fine particulate matter (PM2.5) — particles smaller than 2.5 micrometers in diameter — is considered the most harmful component of air pollution for cardiovascular health. These microscopic particles penetrate deep into the lungs and enter the bloodstream, triggering systemic inflammation, oxidative stress, and endothelial dysfunction. Long-term exposure to elevated PM2.5 levels has been associated with accelerated atherosclerosis, the buildup of fatty deposits in arterial walls that can lead to heart attacks and strokes.

The World Health Organization estimates that outdoor air pollution contributes to approximately 4.2 million premature deaths globally each year, with cardiovascular disease accounting for the largest share — roughly 40% of these deaths. Low- and middle-income countries bear a disproportionate burden, as they tend to have higher pollution levels and weaker regulatory frameworks.

Recent research has highlighted that even short-term spikes in air pollution can trigger acute cardiovascular events in vulnerable individuals, including the elderly, people with pre-existing heart conditions, and those with diabetes. Studies in major cities have documented increases in hospital admissions for heart attacks and strokes on days with high pollution levels.

Public health strategies to mitigate cardiovascular harm from air pollution include strengthening air quality standards, transitioning to clean energy sources, promoting urban green spaces, and advising high-risk individuals to limit outdoor activity during high-pollution days. At the clinical level, physicians are increasingly encouraged to consider air pollution exposure as part of cardiovascular risk assessment.

(Original content — Study2One)

Text 3: Digital Health Literacy in Elderly Populations

The rapid digitalization of healthcare services — from online appointment booking and electronic health records to telemedicine consultations and patient portals — has created significant challenges for elderly populations. Digital health literacy, defined as the ability to seek, find, understand, and appraise health information from electronic sources and apply the knowledge gained to address or solve a health problem, is now essential for effective healthcare navigation.

A cross-sectional study conducted in 12 European countries in 2024 found that only 38% of adults over 65 felt confident using digital health tools, compared to 82% of adults aged 25-44. The study identified several barriers: limited experience with technology, physical challenges such as poor eyesight and reduced fine motor skills, cognitive difficulties in navigating complex interfaces, fear of making errors with personal health data, and a preference for face-to-face communication with healthcare providers.

The consequences of low digital health literacy are not trivial. Elderly patients who cannot access patient portals may miss important test results, medication reminders, or appointment notifications. Those unable to use telemedicine platforms may face longer wait times for in-person visits or forgo care altogether. In essence, the digital transformation of healthcare risks widening existing health inequities along generational lines.

Promising interventions include designing age-friendly digital interfaces with larger text, simpler navigation, and voice-command options; providing free digital literacy workshops at community centers and libraries; training family members and caregivers to serve as digital health navigators; and maintaining non-digital alternatives for essential healthcare services. Researchers stress that digital health equity requires not only improving elderly people's digital skills but also adapting technology to meet their needs.

(Original content — Study2One)
questionText: According to the study, what percentage of adults over 65 felt confident using digital health tools?
explanation: The text states: «only 38% of adults over 65 felt confident using digital health tools, compared to 82% of adults aged 25-44.» Option B matches.

questionText: Which of the following is NOT listed as a barrier to digital health literacy in elderly populations?
explanation: The text lists: limited tech experience, physical challenges (poor eyesight, reduced motor skills), cognitive difficulties, fear of errors with personal data, and preference for face-to-face communication. «High cost of internet services» is NOT mentioned. Option C is correct.

options.text: Poor eyesight and reduced fine motor skills.
Fear of making errors with personal health data.

Text 4: Antimicrobial Resistance — A One Health Approach

Antimicrobial resistance (AMR) occurs when bacteria, viruses, fungi, and parasites evolve to withstand the drugs designed to kill them. The World Health Organization has declared AMR one of the top ten global public health threats. Without effective antimicrobials, routine medical procedures such as surgeries, organ transplants, and cancer chemotherapy become significantly more dangerous, as the risk of untreatable infections rises sharply.

Traditionally, AMR was viewed primarily as a human health problem linked to overuse of antibiotics in clinical settings. However, the One Health approach recognizes that human, animal, and environmental health are interconnected. Approximately 73% of all antimicrobials sold globally are used in livestock production — not to treat sick animals, but as growth promoters and prophylactics. Resistant bacteria can transfer between animals and humans through direct contact, the food chain, and shared water sources. Similarly, pharmaceutical manufacturing waste and agricultural runoff contaminate waterways, creating environmental reservoirs of resistant organisms.

The One Health response to AMR requires coordinated action across multiple sectors. In human health, this means improving diagnostic capabilities to ensure antibiotics are prescribed only when truly needed, strengthening infection prevention and control, and investing in the development of new antimicrobials and alternative therapies. In animal health, it involves phasing out the use of antimicrobials as growth promoters, implementing stricter veterinary oversight of antibiotic use, and improving animal husbandry practices to reduce the need for prophylactic treatments. Environmentally, it demands better regulation of pharmaceutical waste, improved wastewater treatment systems, and monitoring of resistant organisms in ecosystems.

Critics of the One Health approach argue that its broad, multi-sectoral nature makes implementation slow and coordination difficult, particularly in low-resource settings where regulatory capacity is limited. Proponents counter that the interconnected nature of AMR makes a siloed approach — focusing on human health alone — fundamentally inadequate. As resistant infections claim an estimated 1.27 million lives annually and could cause 10 million deaths per year by 2050, the urgency of a comprehensive response cannot be overstated.

(Original content — Study2One)

Text 5: Universal Health Coverage — Progress and Challenges

Universal health coverage (UHC) — the principle that all people should have access to the health services they need without suffering financial hardship — has become a central goal of global health policy. Enshrined in the United Nations Sustainable Development Goals as Target 3.8, UHC encompasses the full spectrum of health services, from prevention and promotion to treatment, rehabilitation, and palliative care.

Progress toward UHC has been uneven. The WHO's UHC Service Coverage Index, which measures access to essential health services on a scale from 0 to 100, showed a global average of 68 in 2021, up from 45 in 2000. However, significant disparities persist. High-income countries average scores above 80, while many low-income countries in sub-Saharan Africa and South Asia score below 40. Furthermore, the COVID-19 pandemic caused unprecedented disruptions to essential health services, reversing years of progress in some regions.

Financial protection remains one of the most challenging dimensions of UHC. Globally, approximately 2 billion people face catastrophic or impoverishing health spending, meaning they must spend more than 10% of their household budget on healthcare or are pushed below the poverty line by medical expenses. Out-of-pocket payments continue to be the primary source of health financing in many developing countries, creating a system where the quality of care a person receives depends largely on their ability to pay.

Innovative financing mechanisms are being explored to close the UHC gap. These include expanding tax-funded public health systems, implementing social health insurance schemes, leveraging digital technology to reduce administrative costs, and increasing international development assistance for health. Some countries have made remarkable strides: Thailand achieved near-universal coverage through its Universal Coverage Scheme, which provides comprehensive services to all citizens for a nominal copayment of roughly one US dollar per visit. Rwanda expanded community-based health insurance to cover over 90% of its population through the Mutuelles de Santé program.

Critics caution that achieving UHC is not simply a matter of financing. Workforce shortages, infrastructure gaps, governance challenges, and the rising burden of non-communicable diseases all threaten to undermine coverage expansion. The WHO estimates a projected shortfall of 10 million health workers globally by 2030, concentrated in the countries that can least afford it.

(Original content — Study2One)
